A few more methods in the assert class will not affect the extensibility of=
 JUnit. Nor will it make JUnit any more difficult to understand. But it wil=
l enable new JUnit users to have more utilities at their fingertips. I thin=
k that most users are confused initially when they come to JUnit because it=
 doesn't do a whole lot. Personally, I don't care a whole lot for my own us=
e, but I think that adding some more utilities to JUnit will enhance it's o=
ut-of-the-box usability. The power users will eventually get under the hood=
 and make extensions where it suits them.

What's confusing to me about the=
 assert class is that it only goes part of the way. It provides a bunch of =
assertions but then an arbitrary line in the sand has been drawn to say tha=
t these are all that anyone should need. This is confusing. I would rather =
see the Assert class simplified down to only one method: assertTrue. This w=
ould then beg for the extensibility you describe and the framework would at=
 least be consistent. Otherwise, we should recognise the Assert class as a =
utility for programmers and load it up. You don't have to the methods there=
 if you don't want to.

Chris
